question_text: Using the presumed PDF approach for mixture fraction in stratified combustion, derive the expression for the mean density (ρ̄) in terms of the Favre-averaged mixture fraction (Z̃) and its variance (Z''²), assuming a beta distribution. Explain the physical significance of the segregation factor (gZ) in this context.
standard_answer: In the presumed PDF approach for stratified combustion, the mean density ρ̄ is derived by integrating the inverse of the density function over the mixture fraction space, weighted by the Favre PDF P̃Z(Z). For a beta distribution, P̃Z(Z) = [Γ(a+b)/(Γ(a)Γ(b))] Z^(a-1) (1-Z)^(b-1), where parameters a and b are related to Z̃ and Z''² via a = Z̃[(1/Z̃) - 1] and b = (1-Z̃)[(1/Z̃) - 1], with the segregation factor gZ = Z''² / [Z̃(1-Z̃)]. The mean density is then ρ̄ = [∫₀¹ (1/ρ(Z)) P̃Z(Z) dZ]^(-1). Assuming adiabatic combustion and ideal gas law, ρ(Z) = ρ_u / (1 + τ c(Z)), where τ is the heat release parameter and c(Z) is the progress variable. For a given Z, ρ(Z) can be obtained from flamelet tables. The segregation factor gZ physically represents the intensity of mixture fraction fluctuations relative to the mean. When gZ → 0, the PDF is narrow, indicating nearly homogeneous mixture, and ρ̄ ≈ ρ(Z̃). When gZ → 1, the PDF is bimodal, with peaks at Z=0 and Z=1, meaning the mixture is highly segregated into pure fuel and air, leading to ρ̄ being dominated by the densities at these extremes. Thus, gZ captures the effect of mixture inhomogeneity on mean thermodynamic properties, which is crucial for accurate prediction of flow and combustion dynamics in stratified systems.
